body_content.explanation: a round, flat piece of minced beef, fried and usually eaten between two halves of a bread roll
beef that is cut into very small pieces, used to make hamburgers
a symbol consisting of three horizontal lines that you can touch or click on to see a menu, for example on a website or phone app:
examples: Every time I click on the hamburger the page scrolls to the top.
The hamburger button is typically found in a top corner of a graphical user interface.
If you’re designing a website, it’s usually recommended that you place hamburger icons in the top left corner of a page.
Click on the hamburger menu (three bars) in the top right corner.

body_content.explanation: a road junction (= where roads come together) consisting of a main road that goes through the middle of a roundabout (= a junction where traffic must go around a circular area in the middle):
examples: The simplest of these road layouts is the hamburger, which ploughs a two-way road through a central island.
